Returning to Spain after generations of exile
subhead: The country is experiencing a sharp rise in population, driven by a wave of 'grandchildren' settling in the land of their ancestors who fled Francoist Spain, a place to which they feel attached, despite never having lived there.

title: The West Bank village of Palestine's forgotten Americans
subhead: In the occupied West Bank, 85% of Turmus Ayya's population are American-Palestinian citizens. Every summer, these dual nationals return to visit their families and maintain ties with their homeland. They find that their American passports offer no immunity from persecution by the army and settlers in this territory, where illegal Israeli settlements are rapidly expanding.

title: Is it ever a good idea to... walk around with a giant mug?
subhead: In fashion, as in life, it is important to know the lines you should not cross. Or else, to do so deliberately.

title: The making of the Agnès b. cardigan
subhead: Since its creation in 1979, the Agnès b. snap cardigan has sold more than two million pieces. Functional and timeless, it has been produced in more than 150 colors and 40 versions, immortalized by world-renowned photographers and even exhibited in museums.

Why foreigners love France but struggle with the French
subhead: While France captivates with its culture and lifestyle, the French, frequently caricatured as arrogant and impolite, often have a poor reputation. This ambivalence raises questions about the roots of anti-French sentiment abroad.

title: Trump turns the government shutdown into a political weapon
subhead: The American president considers the partial halt of government operations − triggered by budget disagreements between Republicans and Democrats − an opportunity to further dismantle the federal state and win a PR war against his opponents.

title: Former American diplomat Robert Malley: 'Trump's Gaza plan offers more ambiguities and potential pitfalls than clear answers'
subhead: In an interview with Le Monde, Robert Malley, who participated in peace negotiations between Israel and Palestine under Bill Clinton, Barack Obama and Joe Biden, sees Donald Trump's plan as yet another attempt that fails to take history into account. In particular, he questions the relevance of the two-state solution.
